@graph.name: Pre-Cancer Atlas Pilot Project (PCAPP) - Human Tumor Atlas Network
Human Tumor Atlas Network

atlas_overview:
There is a lack of in-depth knowledge of the early molecular, cellular, and non-cellular properties that fuel the progression of premalignant lesions to invasive cancers, resulting in a missed opportunity for intervention during this period. The PCA initiative addresses this need by conducting comprehensive characterization of the molecular and cellular features of organ-specific premalignant lesions and their microenvironment, while also capturing the spatial and structural information temporally.

The goal is to construct comprehensive, dynamic, high-resolution, multidimensional, multiparametric, temporal, and scalable atlases of precancerous lesions and their surrounding microenvironment. PCAs will lead to a greater understanding of the biological underpinnings of tumor progression or regression, and drive early detection, risk stratification, and intervention strategies.
data_overview: The biospecimen team is responsible for identifying and collecting cross-sectional and longitudinal biospecimens, processing, ensuring high quality of the samples, and the initial histopathological characterization. The specimens will then be handed over to the characterization team that will use state-of-the-art technologies for molecular, cellular, and non-cellular characterization, and also capture the spatial information at the cellular and/or molecular levels. The data management team, that has been deeply involved in the above steps, will then be responsible for processing, analysis, integration, and predictive modeling of the data to visualize high-resolution structural, functional, and temporal relationships as a dynamic, multidimensional, multiparametric atlas(es) in a searchable and scalable format. The data management team will also be responsible for facilitating broader interactions with other National Cancer Institute (NCI) and National Institutes of Health (NIH) infrastructures, and for disseminating tools and data to the larger research community.
publications: • Srivastava S, Ghosh S, Kagan J, Mazurchuk R; National Cancer Institutes HTAN Implementation. The Making of a PreCancer Atlas: Promises, Challenges, and Opportunities. Trends Cancer. 2018 Aug;4(8):523-536. doi: 10.1016/j.trecan.2018.06.007. Epub 2018 Jul 21. PMID: 30064661.
